    • currentBlockMovedCommand

      private BlockMovedCommand currentBlockMovedCommand
      Since control-Z needs to revert to a previous state, handling dragged blocks becomes a bit tricky. Dragging is not an instantaneous action, so we need to "remember" what state we were in when we start the dragging, so we can return to that state once we release the blocks. That's why we have a blockMovedCommand stored at all times, which we first initialize with the current state, and later update with the info it needs for the release of a block (so first we give it the info for its undo command, later we give it the info for its execute command)

  • Constructor Details

    • EventHandler

  • Method Details

    • getExecutionController

      public ExecutionController getExecutionController()

    • getAreaController

      public AreaController getAreaController()

    • handleMouseEvent

      public void handleMouseEvent​(int id, int x, int y)
      Executes a case depending on what mouse action id was performed and on what area the mouse is positioned.
      Parameters:
      id - The received type of mouse event. We distinguish 3 types: 1) mouse click 2) mouse drag 3) mouse release
      x - The x coordinate of the mouse
      y - the y coordinate of the mouse

    • handleMousePressed

      private void handleMousePressed​(int x, int y)
      Handles a mouse press. If the position of the cursor was inside the game world area upon clicking, we open the interface for loading in a game, and load the game in once it was chosen.

    • handleMouseDragged

      private void handleMouseDragged​(int x, int y)
      Called on each mouse drag update. If draggedBlock is currently null, we look for any block below the position of the cursor to start dragging them. If a block was already being dragged, we update its position to the cursor and highlight any nearby compatible connectors.

    • handleMouseReleased

      private void handleMouseReleased​(int x, int y)
      Handles a mouse release. If no block was being dragged, this function returns instantly. Otherwise, if the block was being dragged over the program area, we add the block to the area. If the cursor position was anywhere else, we remove the dragged blocks from the game. This function finalizes the currentBlockMoved command, executes it and creates a new one for the next movement.

    • handleKeyEvent

      public void handleKeyEvent​(int id, int keyCode, char keyChar, java.awt.event.KeyEvent e)
      Handles a given KeyEvent. This function is used to redirect any inputs to the program to the corresponding function, and has no knowledge about the game itself.
      Parameters:
      id - The received type of key event. Only key presses(id == KeyEvent.KEY_PRESSED) are accepted.
      keyCode - The code of the key being pressed
      keyChar - The character of the key being typed
      e - The entire keyEvent, which can be used to detect whether control or shift is held currently.

    • handleKeyEvent

      public void handleKeyEvent​(java.awt.event.KeyEvent e)

    • executeNewCommand

      private void executeNewCommand​(Command command)
      Executes a given command and removes any undo-history as we are starting a new one.
      Parameters:
      command - The command which should be executed

    • redoAction

      private void redoAction()
      Redoes an action which the user undid in the past. This function takes the topmost Command from the undoHistoryStack and executes it once again. If there is no undo history, this function has no effect. Furthermore, this function cannot be called while the user is currently performing an input (e.g. dragging blocks)

      After this function is called, the command will be moved from the top of the undoHistoryStack to the top of the commandHistoryStack.

    • undoAction

      private void undoAction()
      Undoes the most recent action the user has performed. Every action is stored as a Command and put on a commandHistoryStack. This function takes the topmost (the most recent) command from this stack, calls its Command.undo(), and puts it on the undoHistoryStack. This function cannot be called while the user is currently performing an input (e.g. dragging blocks)

      When this function is completed, the state of the program will be back to the state it was in before the most recent action of the user.

    • showDebug

      private void showDebug()
